citation.article-title: Transfer of Natrialba asiatica B1T to Natrialba taiwanensis sp. nov. and description of Natrialba aegyptiaca sp. nov., a novel extremely halophilic, aerobic, non-pigmented member of the Archaea from Egypt that produces extracellular poly(glutamic acid).
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Cells are non-pigmented rods or coccobacilli, 0.5-0.7x1.3 μm, Gram-negative and motile. The optimum temperature range for growth is 30-40 °C, with a maximum at 50 °C. The pH range for growth is pH 6-8, with an optimum in the range pH 6.6-7. The NaCl range for growth is from 2.0 M to saturation, with an optimum at 4.0 M. NaCl may be replaced to a large extent by KCl (Table 2). Aerobic, catalase and oxidase-positive. Acid produced from xylose, arabinose, sucrose, glucose (weak) and maltose (weak) but not from lactose or starch. Casein and gelatin are hydrolysed, but not starch. Strongly lipolytic on Tweens 20, 40 and 80, as well as using egg yolk (lecithin) as substrate.
Isolated from beach sand in Japan.
The type strain is strain 172P1T, deposited in the DSMZ as DSM 12278T and in the Japan Collection of Microorganisms, Wako, Saitama, Japan, as JCM 9576T.
